title: Northern Ireland court dismisses no-deal Brexit challenge
text:
British Prime Minister Boris Johnson | Pool photo by Julian Simmonds/WPA Pool via Getty Images Northern Ireland court dismisses no-deal Brexit challenge ‘Not appropriate’ for court to dig into potential Brexit outcomes on the basis of ‘political rhetoric,’ says judge.

LONDON — The Court of Appeal in Belfast rejected an appeal by a Northern Irish rights campaigner against British Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s Brexit strategy.

Lawyers for Raymond McCord had said that a no-deal Brexit on October 31 would breach the Good Friday peace agreement that ended three decades of violence on the island of Ireland.

However, Declan Morgan, chief justice of Northern Ireland, dismissed the case today, saying “it is not appropriate for this court to examine the possible outcome of the [Brexit] negotiation on the basis of political rhetoric.”

McCord, whose son was murdered by loyalist paramilitaries in 1997, had filed the legal challenge after Johnson vowed to take the U.K. out of the EU, “do or die,” by October 31. His case was dismissed by the Belfast High Court on September 12, on the grounds that the issues at stake were “political” in nature.
description: ‘Not appropriate’ for court to dig into potential Brexit outcomes on the basis of ‘political rhetoric,’ says judge.
